questions.question: A key difference between GAAP and IFRS conceptual frameworks is that IFRS:

options.A: Does not have a conceptual framework
options.B: Explicitly includes prudence (conservatism) as a component of faithful representation
options.C: Does not recognize assets and liabilities

questions.explanation: The IFRS conceptual framework explicitly includes prudence (the exercise of caution under uncertainty) as supporting faithful representation. GAAP removed conservatism as a specific qualitative characteristic.
questions.tip: IFRS: prudence in framework. GAAP: removed conservatism.

questions.question: Under IFRS, which inventory cost flow method is prohibited?

options.A: FIFO
options.B: Weighted average

questions.explanation: IFRS prohibits the use of LIFO (last-in, first-out). Only FIFO, weighted average, and specific identification are permitted under IFRS.
questions.tip: IFRS: NO LIFO. GAAP: LIFO permitted.

questions.question: Regarding inventory writedowns to net realizable value:

options.A: Both GAAP and IFRS prohibit reversal
options.B: IFRS permits reversal; GAAP prohibits reversal
options.C: GAAP permits reversal; IFRS prohibits reversal

questions.explanation: IFRS permits reversal of inventory writedowns if NRV increases (limited to original writedown). GAAP prohibits reversal—once written down, the new lower cost becomes the basis.
questions.tip: IFRS: can reverse inventory writedown. GAAP: no reversal.

questions.question: For property, plant, and equipment subsequent measurement:

options.A: GAAP permits the revaluation model; IFRS does not
options.B: IFRS permits the revaluation model; GAAP requires cost model

questions.explanation: IFRS permits an accounting policy choice between the cost model and revaluation model for PPE. GAAP requires the cost model (historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment).
questions.tip: IFRS: cost or revaluation model. GAAP: cost model only.

questions.question: Component depreciation for PP&E is:

options.A: Required by IFRS; permitted but not common under GAAP
options.B: Prohibited by both
options.C: Required by GAAP; prohibited by IFRS

questions.explanation: IFRS requires component depreciation—significant parts of an asset with different useful lives must be depreciated separately. GAAP permits it but companies often don't apply it as rigorously.
questions.tip: IFRS: component depreciation required. GAAP: permitted.

questions.question: For impairment losses on long-lived assets (excluding goodwill):

options.A: Both GAAP and IFRS prohibit reversal
options.B: IFRS permits reversal; GAAP prohibits reversal
options.C: GAAP permits reversal; IFRS prohibits reversal

questions.explanation: IFRS permits reversal of impairment losses (except goodwill) if circumstances change. GAAP prohibits reversal of impairment losses—they are considered permanent.
questions.tip: IFRS: can reverse asset impairment. GAAP: no reversal.

questions.question: The impairment test approach differs in that:

options.A: GAAP uses a one-step FV test; IFRS uses recoverable amount
options.B: GAAP uses a two-step approach (recoverability then measurement); IFRS uses one-step recoverable amount
options.D: IFRS uses two steps; GAAP uses one step

questions.explanation: GAAP uses recoverability test first (compare undiscounted cash flows to carrying amount), then measures impairment using fair value. IFRS compares carrying amount directly to recoverable amount (higher of FV less costs to sell and value in use).
questions.tip: GAAP: 2-step (recoverability + FV). IFRS: 1-step (recoverable amount).

questions.question: Development costs are:

options.A: Expensed under both GAAP and IFRS
options.B: Capitalized if criteria are met under IFRS; generally expensed under GAAP
options.C: Capitalized under GAAP; expensed under IFRS

questions.explanation: IFRS requires capitalization of development costs when specific criteria are met (technical feasibility, intent to complete, etc.). GAAP generally expenses R&D, with limited exceptions like software development.
questions.tip: IFRS: capitalize development if criteria met. GAAP: expense R&D.

questions.question: Investment property under IFRS:

options.A: Does not exist as a separate category
options.B: Is a separate category that can be measured at fair value or cost
options.C: Must always be measured at cost
options.D: Is classified the same as under GAAP

questions.explanation: IFRS has a separate 'investment property' category (property held to earn rentals or capital appreciation) with a choice of fair value or cost model. GAAP has no separate investment property category.
questions.tip: IFRS: investment property category (FV or cost). GAAP: no such category.

questions.question: Under IFRS, goodwill is:

options.A: Amortized over 10 years
options.B: Not amortized; tested for impairment annually

questions.explanation: Under both IFRS and GAAP, goodwill is not amortized but tested for impairment at least annually. Note: GAAP now allows private companies to elect amortization.
questions.tip: Goodwill: no amortization under both (GAAP private co. exception).

questions.question: For measuring noncontrolling interest at acquisition:

options.A: Both require fair value
options.B: IFRS allows fair value or proportionate share; GAAP requires fair value
options.C: GAAP allows choice; IFRS requires fair value

questions.explanation: IFRS allows a choice: NCI can be measured at fair value (full goodwill) or at the NCI's proportionate share of identifiable net assets (partial goodwill). GAAP requires fair value (full goodwill).
questions.tip: IFRS: NCI at FV or proportionate share. GAAP: FV only.

questions.question: The revenue recognition standards under GAAP (ASC 606) and IFRS (IFRS 15) are:

options.A: Completely different
options.B: Substantially converged with minor differences
options.D: GAAP uses cash basis; IFRS uses accrual

questions.explanation: ASC 606 and IFRS 15 were jointly developed and are substantially converged. Both use the 5-step model for revenue recognition with only minor differences.
questions.tip: Revenue recognition: substantially converged (ASC 606 = IFRS 15).

questions.question: Under the lease standards (ASC 842 and IFRS 16), a key difference is that IFRS:

options.A: Does not require lessees to recognize lease liabilities
options.B: Has a single lease classification for lessees (all similar to finance leases)

questions.explanation: IFRS 16 has essentially one lessee model—all leases are recognized similarly to finance leases. ASC 842 retains the finance/operating distinction for expense pattern.
questions.tip: IFRS: single lessee model. GAAP: finance vs operating distinction.

questions.question: For classification of interest and dividends on the cash flow statement:

options.A: Both GAAP and IFRS require operating classification
options.B: GAAP has fixed classifications; IFRS allows more flexibility

questions.explanation: GAAP requires interest paid/received and dividends received as operating. IFRS allows interest and dividends to be classified as operating, investing, or financing depending on the nature.
questions.tip: GAAP: fixed classification. IFRS: flexible for interest/dividends.

questions.question: Under IFRS, the balance sheet is typically called:

options.A: Balance sheet (same as GAAP)
options.B: Statement of financial position

questions.explanation: IFRS uses the term 'statement of financial position' while GAAP commonly uses 'balance sheet,' though both terms are acceptable under both frameworks.
questions.tip: IFRS: Statement of Financial Position. GAAP: Balance Sheet.

questions.question: Extraordinary items classification on the income statement:

options.A: Is required under both GAAP and IFRS
options.B: Is prohibited under both GAAP and IFRS

questions.explanation: Both GAAP and IFRS prohibit presenting items as 'extraordinary' on the face of the income statement. Unusual or infrequent items are disclosed separately but not labeled as extraordinary.
questions.tip: No extraordinary items under GAAP or IFRS.

questions.question: IFRS uses the term 'provision' where GAAP uses:

options.A: The same term
options.B: Accrued liability or loss contingency

questions.explanation: IFRS uses 'provision' for liabilities of uncertain timing or amount (what GAAP calls accrued liabilities or loss contingencies). GAAP uses 'provision' mainly for income tax provision.
questions.tip: IFRS provision = GAAP accrued liability/loss contingency.

questions.question: When a range of equally likely outcomes exists for a provision:

options.A: GAAP uses midpoint; IFRS uses minimum
options.B: GAAP uses minimum; IFRS uses midpoint (best estimate)

questions.explanation: GAAP uses the minimum of a range when no amount is more likely. IFRS uses the midpoint (best estimate) for a large population or the most likely outcome for single obligations.
questions.tip: Range: GAAP = minimum. IFRS = midpoint/best estimate.

questions.question: Capitalization of borrowing costs for qualifying assets:

options.A: Is optional under GAAP; required under IFRS
options.B: Is required under both GAAP and IFRS
options.D: Is required under GAAP; optional under IFRS

questions.explanation: Both GAAP and IFRS require capitalization of borrowing costs (interest) for qualifying assets that take substantial time to prepare for use or sale.
questions.tip: Borrowing cost capitalization: required under both.

questions.question: The treatment of prior period errors is:

options.A: Different between GAAP and IFRS
options.B: Substantially the same—retrospective restatement

questions.explanation: Both GAAP and IFRS require retrospective restatement for material prior period errors. Prior periods are corrected as if the error had never occurred.
questions.tip: Error correction: same treatment (retrospective).

questions.question: Earnings per share presentation requirements under GAAP and IFRS are:

options.A: Completely different
options.B: Substantially similar

questions.explanation: EPS requirements are substantially similar under both GAAP and IFRS. Both require basic and diluted EPS on the face of the income statement for public entities.
questions.tip: EPS requirements: substantially the same.

questions.question: Segment reporting under GAAP and IFRS:

options.A: Uses completely different approaches
options.B: Both use the management approach with minor differences
options.D: Uses risk and reward approach under IFRS

questions.explanation: Both GAAP (ASC 280) and IFRS (IFRS 8) use the management approach to identify operating segments. Requirements are substantially converged.
questions.tip: Segment reporting: both use management approach.

questions.question: Biological assets (like livestock and crops) under IFRS are measured at:

options.A: Historical cost
options.B: Fair value less costs to sell
options.D: The same as inventory under GAAP

questions.explanation: IFRS has specific guidance (IAS 41) requiring biological assets to be measured at fair value less costs to sell. GAAP has no specific biological asset standard and typically uses cost.
questions.tip: IFRS: biological assets at FV less costs to sell.

questions.question: A common characterization of GAAP vs IFRS is that:

options.A: GAAP is more principles-based; IFRS is more rules-based
options.B: GAAP is more rules-based; IFRS is more principles-based
options.D: Neither has any rules or principles

questions.explanation: GAAP is often characterized as more rules-based with specific guidance and bright-line tests. IFRS is considered more principles-based, relying more on professional judgment.
questions.tip: GAAP: rules-based. IFRS: principles-based.

questions.question: Fair value measurement guidance under GAAP (ASC 820) and IFRS (IFRS 13):

options.A: Is completely different
options.B: Is substantially converged
options.C: Only GAAP has fair value guidance

questions.explanation: ASC 820 and IFRS 13 were developed through a convergence project and are substantially the same, including the three-level fair value hierarchy.
questions.tip: Fair value measurement: converged standards.
